Our Kindergarten principals, Ms. Hobeck and Mrs. Carbaugh presented their yearly Kindergarten Center report to the Board of Education yesterday evening. The principals stated our students are happy and doing very well with all the changes, including wearing masks.

In the closing of the 2019-2020 school year,

-92% or our Kindergarten students could identify all 26 capital and lowercase letters
- Teachers "met" with every student via video to ensure all students were able to move on to the next grade level
- Teachers took turns videoing themselves reading to the students and posted on Facebook so all students had a chance to be read to every evening by their teachers
- The ISS room was changed to the intervention room

This year, some of the changes are

- Science is being taught through our Project Lead the Way program, which is being taught all the way up through 12th grade
- Reading is being taught through Smarty Ants
- Teachers are learning Google Classroom so all students may continue learning, even if they must miss school for any reason

Straight from the perspective of an elementary teacher in Sikeston.

We may not have all the answers, but we are all trying our best.

Stay kind. Stay patient. Stay trusting.

We’ll all get through this together. #WeAreSikeston
shared_text:
Kristi Stiles Williams
July 29 at 11:46 AM ·

My attempt at social distancing in my 2nd grade classroom at Wing elementary. I have a total of 20 desks. I was able to space them 3 or more feet apart measuring from the legs of one desk to the legs of another desk. Each desk has at least 3 feet of space in front, behind, to the left and the right.
When students are seated at their desks following social distancing they will not be required to wear a mask. When we work in small groups or with a partner, however, we will wear masks. There is no way to give an amount of minutes they will wear or not wear a mask. There will be an amount of time students will work in their individual space each day and there will be time they will work in groups or with a partner during the school day.
I am excited about teaching a new group of wonderful 2nd graders this year!!! I will do all I can to make it the best learning experience! ❤️ 👧 👦

I want to thank you for your patience and understanding as we continue to navigate through this ever changing COVID situation. We will have some answers for you soon.

Good evening,

We hope you and your family are doing well and staying safe, while returning to some sort of normalcy.

Sikeston R-6 has made plans to reopen the school district gradually, keeping in mind the need to protect our staff as well as our patrons. Throughout this gradual reopening, we ask that everyone continues social distancing procedures.

Beginning next Monday, May 11, all offices will be staffed from 8am -3pm to take phone calls. We will still not open to the public just yet. If you need information or need to make plans to pick up or drop off something, please call the school to which this applies.

Beginning the week of May 18th, we begin our district savings schedule, with the entire district being closed on Fridays.

Beginning June 1, if all goes as planned, we want Sikeston R-6 to go back to normal. We will then open to the public.

We want to thank everyone for being patient and willing to provide alternative solutions to every day school business to safeguard our staff, students, and patrons of the school district.
#WeAreSikeston

THIS. This is my biggest achievement. I had the most incredible opportunity to host a Southeast Area Special Olympics Missouri Bowling Showcase. I was able to recruit the most incredible volunteers from Sikeston Public High School! A big s/o to Moll Printing for getting my design on these shirts in two days. Last, but certainly NOT least, Southeast Area SOMO’s staff and Sikeston Parks and Recreation. SPR Director- Dustin Care and Southeast Area SOMO staff:
Development Director- Penny Williams
Program Director - Scott Williams
Program Coordinator- Jen Rose
all gave me the resources and the support to make this dream a reality! I met some amazing athletes, coaches, and parents who want the same goal, to bring more SOMO events to Sikeston. This is what my job is all about! Big smiles and fun memories!

The Paul & Regina Meyer Scholarship application is now available. The application must be turned in by 3:00 pm on March 27th, 2020 to Kim Thornbrough at the high school.

This scholarship is for Sikeston High School graduates who will be enrolled in a graduate or undergraduate program at any accredited college or university in Missouri. Scholarships will be awarded with preference to financial need then scholastic ability. The recipient must be of good moral character. Recipients must maintain a 2.0 GPA.

The application can be found outside the counselors' offices.

Please e-mail Kim Thornbrough at kthornbrough@spsr6.org with any questions.
#WeAreSikeston

SHS students have been learning how to manage money and complete their own tax returns in Personal Students at Sikeston High School have been learning how to manage their money in Personal Finance! They recently finished the TAXES unit and the BANKING units.

The pictures below show mostly high school juniors completing 1040 tax returns, and learning about how our tax system works. Several have even come in on their own time, and e-filed their own simple tax returns.

This past week they learned how to correctly fill out a deposit slip, write a check, and most importantly….keep up with how much goes in and out of their bank accounts. On Monday we will start on online banking simulation where they will practice using online bill payments, mobile banking, and person-to-person payments.

Next up….Budgeting, Credit, and Insurance.

Great job to our Business Education Instructor, Mrs. Chris Spurlock! #WeAreSikeston
